The investment program is the first of its kind in Pakistan. It is also 
one of the first to be developed under Asian Development Bank’s 
(ADB’s) evolving clean energy and environment initiative.  
 
The  investment  program  has  its  context  in  a  road  map  for  the 
energy  sector  as  a  whole,  in  itself  a  product  of  diagnostic  work 
over  recent  years.  The  starting  premise  for  this  work  is  a 
recognition  that  power  and  energy  represent,  together  with 
transport  connectivity  and  water,  major  bottlenecks  to  high  and 
inclusive economic growth in the country. Energy supplies are far 
too dependent on oil imports, the cost of which accounts for a big 
share of the total import bill. Pakistan needs to be more efficient in 
energy  use,  but  also  to  generate  more  power  domestically—
through the use of indigenous resources and by changing the mix 
towards  renewable  resources.  The  diagnostic  work  identified  key 
constraints, challenges, and opportunities. This paved the way for 
defining  a  strategic  framework,  a  new  policy  agenda,  and  action 
plans  over  the  short  to  medium  term.  The  action  plans  are 
sequenced  and  complementary,  with  transactions  involving  the 
private and public sectors, debt and equity finance, and technical 
assistance.  
 
Nationwide power demand is outstripping supply, a trend likely to 
continue  unabated  for  some  time.  To  balance  these,  Pakistan

About 99,000 MW of this is likely to come from thermal power, i.e., 
coal, oil, and gas. But the balance could be met from hydropower 
and  renewable  energy,  which  potentially  are  environmentally 
friendlier.  Hydro  includes  large,  medium  and  small  plants.  This 
program  focuses  on  small  to  medium  plants  with  significant 
environmental benefits. 
 
Total generation capacity from renewable energy (RE) is currently 
at a low 180 MW. But there is considerable scope and opportunity 
to increase it to 9,700 MW by 2030. This will raise RE’s profile and 
its  contribution  to  the  total  energy  mix  to  6%.  This  contribution 
would  be  much  higher  were  medium  to  large  hydropower 
generation facilities to be included under the RE package.  
 
Pakistan’s  renewable  energy  potential  is  greatest  in  the  case  of  
small  to  medium-sized  hydropower  plants,  but  wind,  solar,  and 
biomass resources also have potential. Hydropower resources are 
located  mainly  in  the  northern  and  central  parts  of  the  country, 
wind and solar resources in the southern provinces of Sindh and 
Balochistan, 
respectively.  Pakistan’s  vast  agricultural  base 
provides ample opportunities to develop biomass-based energy. 
 
RE  delivers  on  four  strategic  objectives  given  in  Pakistan’s 
Medium  Term  Development  Framework  (MTDF):  (i)  greater 
energy  security;  (ii)  reasonable  economic  and  financial  returns; 
(iii) improved social equity, especially in rural areas; and (iv) clean 
energy and environmental sustainability.  
 
The  investment  program  for  the  power  sector  as  a  whole  is 
estimated  to  be  $150  billion  (2006–2030)  with  $2.2  billion 
expected  for  RE.  Of  RE,  half  would  be  run-of-the-river  hydro 
plants.  The  rest  is  assigned  to  wind  energy,  solar  power,  and 
biomass.  The  financing  plan  involves  federal  and  provincial 
government  budgets,  but  also  the  private  sector  and  institutions 
such as ADB.  
 
The  fund-raising  strategy  calls  for  a  minimum  critical  mass  but 
also  for  certainty  and  diversity  of  funding  sources.  A  program  of 
this  nature  cannot  be  easily  supported  on  an  ad  hoc  basis,  i.e., 
through  stand-alone  projects  processed  every  two  to  three  years 
in different sectors and different parts of the country. The integrity 
of the investment program as a whole demands a partnership and 
continuity.  It  also  means  flexibility  with  regard  to  subproject 
choice,  a  linkage  of  finance  to  project  preparedness,  financial 
discipline,  and  maturing  physical  investments  with  policy  and 
capacity.  It  is  in  this  context  that  the  authorities  requested  ADB 
support  for  the  program  in  the  form  of  a  multitranche  financing 
facility  (MFF).  Such  support  provides  a  platform  for  financial  as 
well  as  expert  assistance,  blending 
reform  and  capacity 
development with investments.

Performance Indicators and Analysis 

2. 
Pakistan is a net importer of energy. Over the last 5 years, on average it has spent about 
$3.3  billion  annually  on  imported  energy,  equivalent  to  25%  of  the  total  import  bill.  Oil  is  the 
main  cost  item.  During  the  current  fiscal  year  (2006)  this  cost  is  likely  to  exceed  $6  billion–a 
function  of  both  demand  and  price  increases.  Oil  imports  place  a  heavy  burden  on  foreign 
exchange reserves. More than 65% of Pakistan’s electricity comes from thermal sources, a little 
less  than  30%  from  hydro,  and  less  than  1%  from  renewable  and  other  sources.  Despite 
imports, Pakistan’s power supplies are 20% less than they should be. In addition, only 55% of 
the  population  has  access  to  electricity  from  the  national  grid.  The  remaining  45%  use 
kerosene, fuel wood, and other forms of biofuels for lighting, cooking, and heating. Pakistan has 
one of the lowest per capita energy consumptions2 in the world.

program  is  to  support  a  projected  6–8%  growth  in  gross  domestic  product  (GDP).  Energy  is 
essential to high and inclusive growth. The poverty reduction agenda depends on it. A results 
framework is given in Appendix 1. A detailed analysis of the sector is provided in Supplementary

Pakistan  has  considerable  potential  for  developing  a  broad  range  of  renewable  energy

Lessons Learned 

 
 
20. 
Ten power projects approved up to 1983 have been postevaluated. All of these projects 
were  classified  as  generally  successful.  Nonetheless,  the  postevaluation  findings  show 
problems  needing  to  be  avoided  in  future.  The  most  critical  are  delays  in  implementation  and 
cost overruns. The average implementation delay was 2.4 years (with more than three quarters 
of the projects delayed by some 78% of their planned targets). Five of the projects experienced 
an  average  cost  overrun  of  82%,  and  the  other  five  an  average  underrun  of  28%.  There  are 
differences  between  the  various  segments  of  the  power  sector  chain.  Transmission  projects 
have  performed  better  than  others.  ADB-financed  projects  after  1983  show  better  results. 
However,  Karachi  Electric  Supply  Corporation  and  WAPDA  (two  clients  since  that  time)  have 
not delivered on operational targets, in particular regarding system loss-reductions. ADB has yet 
to finance RE projects in Pakistan.  
 
21. 
Three  other  lessons  can  be  taken  from  ADB’s  past  involvement  in  Pakistan’s  power 
sector.  First,  weak  governance  influences  effectiveness  and  performance  on  the  ground.  This 
remained a concern until the authorities established NEPRA as an independent regulator. Since 
then,  NEPRA  has  received  considerable  financial  and  technical  support  from  the  Government 
and  external  agencies  and,  on  the  whole,  it  has  been  doing  a  good  job.  Second,  the  reform 
package did not specifically cater for private sector participation. This limited the entry of private 
funding,  better  technology,  and  modern  management  practices.  It  also  affected  efficiency, 
competition, productivity, and commercial focus. Third, the funding agencies, including ADB, did 
not  invite  civil  society  to  participate  in  a  systematic  and  active  fashion  at  the  time  of  project 
formulation.  This  may  have  discouraged  some  reforms,  accountability,  good  governance, 
competition, and the development of consumer advocacy groups.  
 
22.

account when working on the proposed investment program. The regulator continues to function 
well, although it will be further strengthened through direct support from other agencies, namely

incorporated  into  the  proposed  program,  targeting  broad  RE  sector  constraints  and  specific

The energy sector in Pakistan needs to grow by 12% annually to sustain a GDP growth

25. 
ADB’s sector strategy focuses on reform, investment and capacity. The reform agenda 
targets  creation  of  an  enabling  environment  for  private  and  public  investment  alike.  It  also 
targets development of better tariff regimes, stronger financial management systems, regulation, 
governance,  and  measures  to  facilitate  and  keep  private  sector  investment.  The  investment 
agenda focuses on new facilities and rehabilitation of existing ones, along the chain from supply 
through  transmission  and  distribution.  It  emphasizes  indigenous  resources,  with  a  focus  on 
hydropower.  That  agenda  also  attaches  priority  to  renewable  energy  development  (to  help 
change the energy mix and increase supplies in rural areas) and energy efficiency. The capacity 
agenda  focuses  on  better  regulation  and  regulators;  more  efficient  facilitating  agencies 
(including  those  working  on  developing  public-private  partnerships);  and  improved  planning, 
evaluation,  monitoring  and  reporting,  and  fiduciary  oversight.  The  platform  for  this  strategy  is 
poverty  reduction  and  effectiveness.  It  works  on  selected  bottlenecks  to  sector  development, 
which, in turn, is a bottleneck to rising and inclusive growth.

systems.  However,  operational  costs  are  low  by  comparison,  and  the  operating  lifetime  is 
considerably  higher  than  most  other  RE  systems  (30  years,  with  a  warranty  time  of  15–25 
years).  However,  this  is  only  true  for  the  PV  modules.  In  off-grid  systems  either  stand-by 
generators  as  diesel  or  storage  facilities  as  batteries  are  required.  Both  options  increase 
operation  and/or  capital  costs  and  decrease  economic  lifetimes.  System  choice  will  thus  be  a 
factor behind the successful development and adoption of this form of RE.  
 
4. 
In Pakistan, other than the use of bagasse for self-generation in the sugar industry, and 
some  work  on  better  cook  stove  designs,  virtually  none  of  biomass  conversion  or  end  use 
technologies  has  been  deployed  beyond  an  experimental  stage.  Under  the  RE  policy,  the 
Government  plans  to  facilitate  the  construction  of  municipal  waste-to-energy  power  plants 
based on landfill methane recovery and/or direct incineration of municipal solid waste, as well as 
methane-based  power  production  from  dung-fuelled  biodigesters  set  up  by  the  private  sector 
independently or in partnership with the public sector in and around the major towns and cities.  
There is considerable potential for this form of energy.

There  are  major  weaknesses  at  the  federal,  provincial  and  project  level.    These  are 
being  dealt  with.  However,  investment  programs  such  as  the  one  targeting  RE  development 
need  targeted  and  concerted  actions  if  they  are  to  respond  to  policy,  planning,  evaluation, 
monitoring,  and  reporting  issues.    Information,  especially  on  best  practice  for  project 
development,  is  scarce  and  capacity  for  project  preparation  (including  due  diligence)  and 
implementation is weak. RE is quite a new concept at both federal and provincial levels. There 
is no clear institutionalized system or practice for the sector, data collection is not extensive, and 
there  is  limited  expertise  on  economic,  technical,  financial  and  safeguards  issues.  This  can 
change  quickly  but  the  greatest  expertise  at  the  moment  lies  mostly  with  traditional  energy 
sources.  There  has  been  negligible  research  and  development  on  appropriate  technology  for 
RE. This is a particular issue for off-grid applications, where site- and region-specific solutions 
are common in other developing countries. Despite being one of the  most open  economies in 
the  region,  Pakistan  still  faces  lengthy  pre-development  and  negotiation  processes,  which 
impair the supply of equipment and materials.  This affects wind and solar projects in particular, 
for which global supply shortages causes long lead times and price pressures. 
 
7. 
A  new  RE  policy  framework  has  been  developed  for  Pakistan.  This  is  supported  by 
provincial RE policies based on the renewable energy development road map. The Government 
has  prepared  an  investment  program  for  the  sector.    The  policy  framework  supports  this 
program, which focuses on RE development in the short to medium term (up to 2010). Within 
this  period,  the  Government  will  finalize  a  more  comprehensive  renewable  energy  policy  to 
provide  a  longer-term  development  perspective.  The  Government  has  also  completed 
guidelines for determination of tariff for wind power generation in 2006. ADB has been working 
with the Government on policy issues and on the definition of the proposed investment program.     
 
8. 
The Government is aware of the need for private sector participation to deliver volume, 
efficiency  and  financing.  To  meet  an  additional  power  generation  requirement  of  143,310  MW 
during  2005–2030,  a  Medium  Term  Development  Framework  2005–2030  (MTDF)  has  been 
developed.    The  MTDF  calls  for  investment  in  all  sources  of  energy  equivalent  to  $150  billion 
($6  billion  a  year),  of  which  about  $2  billion  a  year  will  come  from  the  public  sector.  The 
remaining $4 billion will be funded by external sources, including the private sector and banks.  
The private sector will be allowed to operate with a range of project modalities, including build-
operate-transfer (BOT) and private–public partnerships (PPP). Multilateral banks such as ADB 
and the World Bank are also potential financiers. In 2002, the Government set out its Policy for 
Power  Generation  Projects  (PPGP),  providing  a  set  of  incentives,  along  with  a  regulatory 
regime, to attract the private sector. Provincial power generation policies are in the first stage of 
implementation in NWFP and Punjab. These are based on the PPGP and will open the way for 
private sector investment.

Objective. Recognizing the need for energy security, the Government has set out a road

from  hydro,  and  1%  from  other  sources.  Even  with  all  this  imported  energy,  Pakistan  faces  a 
20% power shortage. Only 55% of the population has access to electricity from the national grid.

and heating. Increase in generation capacity is closely linked to poverty reduction.

TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE FOR RENEWABLE ENERGY POLICY FORMULATION AND 
CAPACITY DEVELOPMENT OF THE ALTERNATIVE ENERGY DEVELOPMENT BOARD 

 
1. 
In  line  with  the  proposed  Renewable  Energy  Development  Sector  Investment  Program 
(REDSIP) under ADB’s Multitranche Financing Facility (MFF), the Government of Pakistan (the 
Government) finds the inadequacy of its existing renewable energy (RE) Policy Framework. The 
present Framework needs to be expanded to cover the rules, implementation regulations, and 
details of appropriate incentives to promote RE development. It also needs to be converted to a 
comprehensive  Renewable  Energy  Policy  (RE  Policy)  for  the  country  to  provide  long  term 
development perspective. During the appraisal Mission of proposed RESDIP, the Government 
requested  technical  assistance 1  (TA)  for  (i)  formulation  of  RE  policy  and  (ii)  developing 
institutional capacity of Alternative Energy Development Board (AEDB) to implement RESDIP in 
line with the Framework Financing Agreement between the Government and ADB. 
 
2. 
The  Alternative  Energy  Development  Board  (AEDB)  was  created  in  2003  to  act  as 
facilitating agency coordinating both at federal and provincial agencies. Key aspects of AEDB’s 
mandate  are  to:  (i)  act  as  the  central  agency  for  awareness  raising,  policy  and  regulatory 
development,  and  establishment  of  domestic  technologies  and  manufacturing  facilities  for  RE; 
(ii) lower barriers for the introduction of RE and develop market-based incentives to promote RE 
investments, especially from the private sector; and (iii) initiate and incubate RE projects. ADB, 
together  with  other  development  partners,  e.g.,  United  Nations  Development  Programme 
(UNDP) and Deutsche Gesellschaft für Technische Zusammenarbeit (GTZ), has assisted AEDB 
to  enhance  its  capacity.  As  a  result,  a  draft  RE  Policy  Framework  for  the  country  has  been 
prepared  and  time-bound  targets  have  been  set  in  for  RE  development.  AEDB  has  been  also 
successful in coordinating small-medium size hydro power development in provincial levels and 
wind-power  expansion  with  the  support  from  independent  power  producers,  in  particular  in 
Sindh  province.  However,  AEDB’s  institutional  capacity  needs  to  be  further  strengthened  to 
implement the time-bound RE development program. AEDB is expected to play a pivotal role for 
implementation  of  the  proposed  RESDIP  as  a  facilitator  among  various  federal  and  provincial 
agencies. (More details are given in Supplementary Appendix F) 
 
A. 

Purpose and Output  

3. 
The goal of the TA is to facilitate the process of the development of Renewable Energy 
Policy  of  Pakistan.  The  purpose  of  the  Policy  is  to  expedite  the  process  of  developing 
indigenous,  nonpolluting,  and  renewable  sources  of  energy  to  help  meet  Pakistan’s  power 
shortage  and  improve  the  quality  and  reliability  of  the  power  system,  including  such  issues  in 
rural  areas.  This  will  also  help  addressing  energy  security  concerns  and  poverty  reduction 
program of the Government. The TA will result in: (i) allowing AEDB to timely finalize RE policy 
and  carry  out  its  mandate  to  facilitate  and  coordinate  various  RE  initiatives,  and  (ii)  capacity 
development of existing and new AEDB staff. 
 
B. 

Methodology and Key Activities  

There will be two main components of the proposed TA. The first one is to facilitate the

covers  the  capacity  development  of  the  Alternative  Energy  Development  Board  (AEDB).  The

enhanced capacity of AEDB.  The TA will help increase the use of RE in Pakistan and decrease 
reliance  of  imported  fossil  fuels.  It  will  help  address  energy  security  concerns  while  reducing 
poverty  in  particular  in  rural  areas.  No  adverse  social  or  environmental  impacts  are  expected.

The  eight  subprojects  identified  under  the  first  tranche  of  the  proposed  investment

consistent with the loan repayment cycle of 20 years, including a 5-year grace period. The 
residual  capital  asset  value  was  estimated  using  a  2%  depreciation  rate  over  the  assets’ 
economic  lives  of  50  years.  Financial  prices  reflect  market  prices  for  goods  and  services, 
including a 5% duty levied on imported equipment. The exchange rate of PRs60 = $1 was 
used  for  purposes  of  the  analysis.  Incremental  financial  benefits  were  limited  to  sales  of 
electricity generated from the eight subprojects2 to the Central Power Purchasing Authority, 
acting  as  agent  for  National  Transmission  and  Despatch  Company  (NTDC)  or  distribution 
companies.  Operation  and  maintenance  costs  were  estimated  at  3%  of  total  capital 
expenditure, and an allowance for plant overhaul after 10 years of operation was made, at a 
cost  of  20%  of  original  capital  expenditure.  Annual  insurance  expense  at  0.25%  of  initial 
capital  expenditure  was  allowed.  Plant  energy  use  at  0.5%  of  gross  generation  was 
assumed,  and  average  plant  availability  of  97%  modeled. 3 Under  federal  and  provincial 
government policies, owners of small hydropower projects need not pay income or turnover 
tax, although Punjab may impose a water use charge of PRs0.15/kWh.4

Pakistan has incurred significant increase in tariffs due to its heavy dependence on thermal 
power generation (i.e., imported oil) and recently adopted the long-term strategy to enhance 
use of less-costly resources via increasing the share of hydro, coal, and alternative energy in 
the  overall  energy  mix.  Provided  the  current  average  generation  tariff  level  of  about

even  more  evident  because  current  retail  as  well  as  generation  tariff  levels  are  intensely 
exposed to upward pressure due to rising fuel costs. The proposed hydropower generation 
tariffs  are  the  least-cost  option  available  and  the  financial  sustainability  of  implementing 
agencies (IAs) with the proposed indicative off-take tariffs are found to be fully satisfactory.

1. 
Financial projections and analyses have been prepared for Sarhad Hydel Development 
Organization  (SHYDO)  and  Punjab  Power  Development  Company  (PDC).  While  there  will  be 
separate  power  purchase  agreements  for  each  plant  (with  SHYDO  and  PDC  as  the  power 
producers),  they  will  be  simple  and  standardized,  as,  in  essence,  there  is  a  single  wholesale 
buyer (the Central Power Purchasing Authority, acting as agent for National Transmission and 
Despatch  Company  [NTDC]  or  distribution  companies).  Financial  sustainability  of  NTDC  and 
distribution companies, as ultimate purchasers of electricity from the subprojects, will depend on 
their  ability  to  pass  through  bulk  tariff  increases  to  end-users.  Thus,  the  multi-year  retail  tariff 
determinations  of  National  Electric  Power  Regulating  Authority  (NEPRA)  are  important  in 
allowing distributors and NTDC to recover bulk electricity costs through retail tariffs. Therefore, 
financial sustainability of these entities is ultimately a function of the regulator’s ability to set and 
reset  cost-reflective  tariffs  and  of  their  affordability  to  end-use  consumers.  Once  a  tariff  is  set 
and a retrieve collection system is in place, SHYDO and PDC will have no problems with their 
financial sustainability. Domestic inflation is projected using domestic cost escalation factors for 
2006–20101 published  by  ADB  and  at  7.0%  per  year  from  2010  onward.  International  inflation 
forecasts use the international cost escalation factors 2005–20092 published by the World Bank, 
and  thereafter  are  assumed  to  increase  at  2%  per  year.  Exchange  rate  forecasts  have  been 
made on the basis of inflation differentials. More details are in Supplementary Appendix I. 
 
2.

$753  million.3 Punjab  Irrigation  and  Power  Department’s  (Punjab  IPD’s)  long-term  investment 
plans  are  relatively  smaller.  They  are  mostly  confined  to  canal-based  small-scale  low  head 
hydropower plants. SHYDO has four ongoing projects. Its Malakand-III is financed by 60% debt 
and 40% equity, while the remaining three are 100% financed by the Annual Development Fund 
of  NWFP’s  provincial  government.  Punjab  IPD  has  two  ongoing  projects,  Khokhra  and  LBDC

measurable rate where long-term investment plans are not available. Detailed assumptions for 
SHYDO and Punjab IPD (PDC) are in Supplementary Appendix I. Financing plans of on-going 
investments are taken as per existing arrangements. Interest and principal repayments of ADB-

A.

off-peak transmission losses of 2% and 1% of gross generation respectively, were assumed, as 
were peak and off-peak technical distribution losses of 15% and 8%, respectively. An oil price of 
$40 per barrel (bbl) has been used as a base case for economic internal rate of return (EIRR) 
calculations, and sensitivities tested higher bound oil prices of $35/bbl and $50/bbl.

2.

Transmission  and  Dispatch  Company  (NTDC)  was  requested  to  undertake  the  specific  Wien 
Automatic  System  Planning  (WASP)  runs.  The  WASP  IV  program  is  the  primary  means  by

demand forecast for supply from the national grid for 2010, 2015, and 2020 are 17.4, 26.8, and 
38.0  thousand  MW,  respectively.  Demand-supply  analysis  based  upon  the  medium-term 
forecast shows that the NTDC system will have capacity shortfalls in 2006, 2008, and 2010 of 
400, 1,200 and 5,138 MW, respectively. Capacity includes all ongoing and committed projects. 
The least-cost expansion plan included all types of candidate plants, covering (i) hydroelectric 
plants for which feasibility studies are underway or are planned, (ii) coal-fired plants using local 
coal, (iii) base load combined cycle plants fired by imported and domestic gas, (iv) open cycle

WTP, (ii) nonincremental peak-period output (assumed to be 4 hours/day) valued at the LRMC

Description of the Environment 

B. 
 
2. 
Punjab Province: Punjab forms part of Indus Basin Watershed System. The landscape 
of the whole province has been changed completely by development in the last 100 years of the 
largest canal  system  in the  world.  The  subprojects  are  located  in  plain areas  with elevation  in 
the  range  of  50–150  m above  mean  sea  level.  The  subproject  areas  fall  in  a  moist  temperate 
zone that receives rains in the summer monsoon. Some residual precipitation is also received in 
the winter months due to western Mediterranean winds. The lowest and highest values of mean 
monthly  maximum  temperature  are  about  5°  C  and  42°  C  during  the  months  of  January  and 
June, respectively. The soils of the subproject areas are characterized as alluvium deposits of 
sandy loam and sandy silt. According to the Seismo-Tectonic Map of Pakistan, the subproject 
area  belongs  to  one  of  the  least  active  earthquake  zones  in  the  country,  rated  Zone  0.  The 
canals deliver an almost uniform irrigation water flow for 11 months of the year. The people of 
the subproject areas depend upon the canals to meet their household water needs.  
 
Because  of  extensive  cultivation,  high  population,  and  human  activities,  there  is  little 
3. 
wildlife  in  the  subproject  areas.  There  are  no  protected  areas  close  to  any  of  the  subproject 
areas.  There  are  no  natural  forests  in  the  vicinity  of  the  subproject  areas.  However,  the  trees 
along  canals  planted  by  irrigation  and  power  departments  and  forestry  departments  fall  in  the 
category  of  reserved  forests.  Local  farmers  are  practicing  a  small  degree  of  farm-forestry  to 
meet  their  fuel  wood  and  other  day-to-day  needs.  Ever  since  the  irrigation  canal  system  was 
developed,  cotton,  rice,  sugarcane  and  wheat  have  been  the  main  crops.  More  recently, 
however, cotton and sugar cane cultivation has been replaced by maize and potatoes in many 
areas. The fisheries department reports that the main fish species found in the canal system are 
Gulfam,  Rahoo,  and  Mohri.  Because  of  the  construction  of  several  barrages  on  the  river 
network, migratory species have almost become extinct in Punjab waters.  
 
The  subproject  areas  have  a  reasonably  well-developed  communication  infrastructure

and other highways such as Gujranwala-Sialkot road. Other cities and towns are connected to

is in the form of winter snow, which is brought by western Mediterranean winds. Annual mean

6. 
Soils of the subproject areas are mostly a mixture of varying degrees of alluvial deposits, 
where sizeable concentrations of organic matter are found in bowl-shaped valley depressions. 
Such  places  are  used  for  agriculture,  where  terraced  fields  are  found  on  the  steep  mountain 
slopes.  The  project  area  has  abundant  water  resources.  In  the  last  10  years,  local  level 
electricity generation units have also been installed on these water sources. The region also has 
many  fresh  water  springs,  which  are  tapped  by  the  residents  to  meet  domestic  water 
requirements.  According  to  the  Seismo-Tectonic  Map  of  Pakistan,  a  sizeable  part  of  Swat 
Kohistan belongs to one of the major earthquake zones, where in the recent past earthquakes 
up to a magnitude of 6.5 on the Richter scale have been observed. According to the Structural 
Geology  and  Tectonics  map,  the  main  earthquake  centers  fall  within  a  circle  of  50  km  radius 
around Madyan. The Daral Khawar and Ranolia area is in a relatively calm zone.  
 
7. 
The  common  mammals  reported  from  the  Daral  Khawar  and  Ranolia  areas  and  their 
adjoining valleys are monkeys, markhor, musk deer, black bear, brown bear, wolf, leopard cat, 
and panther. Besides common birds, some significant species of the project area are Himalayan 
chakor,  snow  cock,  koklas  pheasant,  and  snow  partridge.  There  are  a  variety  of  highly 
endangered  and  rare  pheasants  in  the  Kohistan  area,  including  monal,  white  crested  Khalij, 
snow cock, Koklas, snow partridge, and the most endangered western tragopan. Snow leopard, 
brown  bear,  musk  deer  and  snow  partridge  have  declining  population  and  are  classified  as 
endangered species. In the immediate Ranolia site area there is degraded habitat and no threat 
exists to any rare or endangered species. Forests in the entire Swat and Kohistan area fall into 
the  protected  category.  The  subproject  areas  have  high  hill  coniferous  forests,  which  are 
associated with the dry-temperate climate zone. Very limited data is available for fish species in 
the Swat River system, and almost none for Daral Khwar, which is a tributary of the same. The 
fish  species  known  as  Swati  (Schizothorax  plagiostomas)  is  found  in  most  rivers  of  NWFP. 
Brown trout have been introduced to Swat River, where, in certain streams they have done well. 
The socioeconomic status of the project area has been described in detail in the IEE.

Subprojects information has been disclosed and disseminated by the Executing Agency 
(EA)  through  public  consultation.  A  resettlement  information  leaflet  containing  information  on 
compensation and resettlement options was made available in local languages and distributed 
to  affected  persons.  The  project  management  unit  (PMU)  through  Environmental  and  Social 
Development  Cell  (ESDC)  and  the  PMUs  has  conduct  consultations  in  affected  villages  to 
explain the resettlement plan in coordination with village and community leaders. Each affected 
person  will  be  provided  information  regarding  specific  entitlements.  Disputes  on  entitlements 
can  be  forwarded  to  the  project  implementation  unit  for  appropriate  action.  The  summary 
resettlement plan (RP) will be disclosed on the ADB website, and information dissemination and 
consultation will continue throughout the project implementation period. 
 
5. 
A  grievance  redress  committee  (GRC)  will  be  formed  to  ensure  affected  persons’ 
grievances are addressed and appropriated actions are taken to resolve them. The committee 
members of a GRC will include affected person representatives, and especially representatives 
of  vulnerable  affected  persons,  local-level  IA/PMU  staff,  local  governments,  respected  citizens 
in diverse professions, non government organizations (NGOs), community-based organizations, 
and local civil and interest groups. The head of a locally elected body will head the GRC. The 
GRC  will  meet  every  2  weeks  especially  during  the  land  acquisition  and  resettlement  phase. 
After  that,  it  will  meet  as  and  when  grievances  are  referred  to  it  to  redress.  The  main 
responsibilities of the GRC are to (i) help APs’ in resolving issues arising from land and property 
acquisition  processes;  (ii)  record,  categorize,  prioritize,  and  resolve  APs’  grievances;  (iii) 
immediately inform the PMU of serious issues and problems; and (iv) inform affected persons of 
the decisions of the GRC and PMU. Each GRC will review grievances involving all resettlement 
benefits,  compensation,  relocation,  and  other  assistance.  Detailed  investigation  will  be 
undertaken  which  may  involve  field  investigation  with  the  affected  persons  concerned. 
Grievances  will  be  redressed  within  2–3  weeks  from  the  dates  of  lodging  the  complaints.  The 
GRC will continue to function during the life of the project, including the defects liability period.  
 
D. 
 
All  affected  persons  will  be  provided  with  compensation  and  resettlement  assistance  if 
6. 
their  lands  are  permanently  or  temporarily  acquired,  their  income  sources  are  adversely 
affected, their homes are fully or partially affected, and such other properties as commercial or 
agricultural structures, crops, trees, and other facilities or access to properties are damaged or 
reduced due to subprojects. Lack of legal documents of their customary rights of occupancy or 
titles shall not affect their eligibility for compensation. In case of land acquisition where land-for-
land  is  not  a  feasible  option,  the  RP  stipulates  payment  of  compensation  based  on  assessed 
replacement or market value of land and structures to affected persons. Temporary land losers 
will be in charge of land clearance and will be therefore compensated for the provision of labor 
at the minimum agricultural wage rate for the duration of this activity.  
 
7. 
In addition to compensation payments in accordance with the LAA, affected persons will 
receive  additional  assistance  to  match  replacement  costs  (the  difference  between  the 
replacement  value  and  the  assessed  value)  for  lost  land  and  structures;  transaction  costs 
including but not limited to stamps and registration costs for the purchase of replacement land; 
and  other  forms  of  resettlement  assistance  such  as  transition  and  shifting  allowances,  and 
agricultural inputs for re-establishing crops. Losses of profits and income due to property loss or 
loss of access to property, regardless of whether the affected person is titled or non-titled, will 
be compensated. To restore income losses, there will be compensation for lost workdays and/or

10. 
The EA will engage the services of an independent agency not associated with project 
implementation to undertake external monitoring and evaluation of resettlement implementation. 
The  external  monitoring  agency  will  have  experience  in  resettlement  implementation  and  a 
satisfactory  familiarity  with  lands  laws  and  regulations  and  ADB’s  involuntary  resettlement 
policy.  It  will  be  hired  in  consultation  with  ADB  within  3  months  of  the  loan  effectiveness.  The 
agency will monitor and verify RP implementation to determine whether resettlement goals have 
been  achieved  and  livelihood  and  living  standards  have  been  restored  or  improved.  It  will 
highlight  weaknesses  in  the  implementation  process  with  recommendations  on  how  to 
overcome  them.  The  external  monitoring  of  the  project  will  be  done  twice  a  year  and  impact 
evaluation  during  the  midterm  review  of  resettlement  implementation  and  at  the  end  of  the 
subproject. Monitoring will indicate whether affected persons understood their entitlements and 
their views on resettlement site conditions. It will evaluate compensation valuation methods and 
disbursement, grievance redress procedures, and staff competencies. The external monitor will 
also evaluate the performance of the ESDC, PMU, and NGOs. The external agency will report 
its findings simultaneously to the EA and to ADB twice a year. Provisions will be made in each 
RP for engaging an external resettlement implementation monitor.
